review.title: Overview of the NLPCC 2015 Shared Task: Chinese Word Segmentation and POS Tagging for Micro-blog Texts
review.abstract: Word segmentation and Part-of-Speech (POS) tagging are two fundamental tasks for Chinese language processing. In recent years, word segmentation and POS tagging have undergone great development. The popular method is to regard these two tasks as sequence labeling problem, which can be handled with supervised learning algorithms such as Conditional Random Fields (CRF). However, the performances of the state-of-the-art systems are still relatively low for the informal texts, such as micro-blogs, forums. In this shared task, we wish to investigate the performances of Chinese word segmentation and POS tagging for the micro-blog texts.

metadata.title: Overview of the NLPCC 2015 Shared Task: Chinese Word Segmentation and POS Tagging for Micro-blog Texts

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Word segmentation and Part-of-Speech (POS) tagging are two basic tasks for Chinese language processing. In recent years, word segmentation and POS tagging have undergone a major development, and the popular method is to treat these two tasks as sequence marking problems [7, 5] that can be treated with monitored learning algorithms such as Maximum Entropy (ME) [1], Perceptron [2], Conditional Random Fields (CRF) [3]. After years of intensive research, Chinese word segmentation and POS tagging are achieving quite high precision, but their performance for the practical requirements for analyzing Chinese texts, especially informal texts, is not as satisfactory. The main reason for this is that most commented corpora Xiv: 150 5.07 599v 3 [cs.C Lau's message texts are not able to work well with texts outside the text domains. In this joint task, we focus on the POS and the joint assessment of the POS.

sections.heading: 2 Data
sections.text: Unlike the popular newswire dataset, we use relatively informal texts from Sina Weibo1. Training and test data consist of microblogs from various fields such as finance, sports, entertainment, etc. Both training and test files are UTF-8 encoded. Data set information is presented in Table 1. OOV rate is slightly higher than other benchmark datasets. For example, the OOV rate in the popular division [9] of the Chinese Treebank dataset (CTB 6.0) is 5.58%, while the OOV rate in our dataset is 7.25%. This dataset contains a total of 35 POS tags. For a detailed list of POS tags, see Table 2.1http: / / weibo.com /

sections.heading: 2.1 Background Data
sections.text: In addition to the training data, we also provide the background data from which the training and test data are drawn. The goal is to find the more demanding features in an unsupervised way.

sections.heading: 3 Description of the Task
sections.text: In this joint task, we would like to examine the performance of Chinese word segmentation and POS marking for microblog texts.

sections.heading: 3.1 Subtasks
sections.text: This task focuses on the two basic problems of Chinese language processing: word segmentation and POS tagging, which can be divided into two subtasks: 1. SEG Chinese word segmentation 2. S & T Common Chinese word segmentation and POS tagging.

sections.heading: 3.2 Tracks
sections.text: Each participant may submit the three runs for each sub-task: Closed Track Run, Semi-Open Track Run and Open Track Run.1. In the closed track, participants could only use information contained in the provided training data. Information such as externally received word counts, part of the language information or name lists were excluded. 2. In the semi-open track, participants could use the information obtained from the provided background data in addition to the provided training data. Information such as externally received word counts, part of the language information or name lists were excluded. 3. In the open track, participants could use the information that should be public and easy to obtain.

sections.heading: 4 Participants
sections.text: Sixteen teams have registered for this task. Finally, there are 27 qualified results submitted by 10 teams. A summary of the qualified participating teams is shown in Table 3.

sections.heading: 5 Results
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.1 Evaluation Metrics
sections.text: The benchmarks are precision, recall and an evenly weighted F1.

sections.heading: 5.2 Baseline Systems
sections.text: Currently, the common method of word segmentation is discriminatory character-based sequence labeling. Each character is referred to as one of {B, M, E, S} to indicate segmentation. {B, M, E} represents the beginning, middle, end of multi-character segmentation, and S represents one-character segmentation. In common word segmentation and POS tagging, the state-of-the-art method is also based on cross-labeling sequence learning that avoids the problem of error propagation and can achieve higher performance in both subtasks [4]. Each label is the cross-product of sequence labeling and a tagging label, e.g. {B-NN, I-NN, E-NN, S-NN,...}. Characteristics are generated by position-based templates at character level. (Sequence labeling is the task of assigning labels y = 1, y1).

sections.heading: 5.3 Chinese word segmentation
sections.text: In terms of word segmentation, the best performances are 95.12, 95.52 and 96.65 for closed, semi-open and open tracks. The best system outperforms the basic systems on closed tracks. The best system on semi-open tracks is better2https: / / github.com / xpqiu / fnlp / 3http: / / taku910.github.io / crfpp / than the closed track. Unsurprisingly, performances on open tracks are increasing strongly.

sections.heading: 5.4 Joint Chinese word segmentation and POS Tagging
sections.text: In common word segmentation and POS marking, the best performances are 88.93, 88.69 and 91.55 for closed, semi-open and open tracks.

sections.heading: 6 Analysis
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: The NLPCC 2015 Shared Task on Chinese Word Segmentation and POS Tagging for Micro-blog Texts focuses on basic research in Chinese language processing. It is the first time that the micro-texts are used to assess the performance of the most advanced methodologies.In future work, we hope to operate an online evaluation system to accept open registration and submission. Currently, a simple system is available at http: / / nlp.fudan.edu.cn / nlpcc2015. The system also gives the leaderboards the latest results among the various tasks and tracks. We also want to expand the scope of the corpus and add more informal texts.

sections.heading: Acknowledgement
sections.text: We are very grateful to the students from our laboratory for their efforts to comment and verify the data. We would also like to thank the participants for their valuable feedback and comments.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we give an overview for the shared task at the 4th CCF Conference on Natural Language Processing & Chinese Computing (NLPCC 2015): Chinese word segmentation and part-of-speech (POS) tagging for micro-blog texts. Different with the popular used newswire datasets, the dataset of this shared task consists of the relatively informal micro-texts. The shared task has two sub-tasks: (1) individual Chinese word segmentation and (2) joint Chinese word segmentation and POS Tagging. Each subtask has three tracks to distinguish the systems with different resources. We first introduce the dataset and task, then we characterize the different approaches of the participating systems, report the test results, and provide a overview analysis of these results. An online system is available for open registration and evaluation at http://nlp.fudan.edu.cn/nlpcc2015.
